I dug around using ChatGPT and got "particle agglomeration or coagulation in colloidal suspensions".  Here is the full answer:  From the excerpt provided, it appears that the problem being discussed is related to particle agglomeration or coagulation in colloidal suspensions. The problem involves understanding the behavior of larger particles when they are influenced by smaller particles in a fluid mixture, as well as their preference for clustering together or sticking to the walls of the container.  The problem is focused on quantifying the extent to which larger particles prefer one configuration over the other (clustering together or adhering to the walls). Understanding these interactions and preferences is essential in various fields, such as material science, chemistry, and environmental engineering, where the properties of colloidal suspensions play an important role.  To analyze this problem, the calculation of the overlap region between two adjacent larger particles is required, as mentioned in the excerpt. The provided formula can be used to calculate the volume of that overlap region, which can further help in understanding the extent to which larger particles prefer clustering together or sticking to the container walls.

Inputting 100 cubic centimeters and 1 cubic meter yielded different answers because the inputs were different.  One cubic meter equals one million cubic centimeters because we're calculating in the 3rd dimension. In the 2nd dimension, one square meter equals ten thousand square centimeters, and in the 1st dimension, one meter does equal one hundred centimeters.  When converting units in higher dimensions, you square or cube the conversion factor.

why not simply convert to the units needed before starting the calculations?

To those confused with why y's units need not be consistent with x's units:  say, the population of rabbits grows exponentially with time that: where A is the initial number of rabbits, Y is the final number of rabbits, Y= A^t.  So are we saying we should say the number of rabbits at time t should have units rabbits^time? No, rabbits are still counted in rabbits.

Beware of his explanation of y= x².  There is a well-defined method of handling this situation where units are treated as mathematical objects.  If x represents some real number times centimeters, like 5cm, then x² = 25cm².  There is no other correct interpretation.  Therefore, y = 25cm², and is an area.  If, like mafl25 writes, he really means the square of the "magnitude", then he should realize that a number without a unit has no magnitude—it's just a number.  Is 10 a big number?  Or is it a small number?  What is its magnitude?  If y is really the square of the "coefficient" of x, then he must isolate the coefficient by dividing x by cm.  That is, he should write y=(x/cm)² cm, or y=x²/cm.  If you then carry out the rest of the problem, treating units as mathematical constants, you will arrive at the correct solution with the correct units.  This is common practice in solving physics problems.  Always be strict and always get the right answer.  There is no paradox here.

The point is that the parabola has an intrinsic length specified by its shape. This length is the diameter of the horizontal slice containing the focus of the parabola. The formula for the volume of the paraboloid is actually: (Pi a^2 k)/2 where k is the length in the parabola, therefore a volume is obtained and the units match up. The slim cauldron has k=1cm and the fat cauldron has k=1m. This is why the volume of the fat cauldron is 100 times bigger.

Indeed, I think I must have made a mistake. The proper way to construct the equation should be: dY/dt = kY, where k is a constant with units (time^-1), and Y is in units of rabbits.  Solving the differential equation you get the general solution Y = Ce^(kt) and C is a constant that must have the units rabbits and both e^(kt) and kt are dimensionless. Now C can be taken to be the number of rabbits at time t=0. I apologize for my poor example; I have learned more over the past year.

yessopie What about a quadratic equation like y = ax^2 + bx + c?

Then you're saying y = 25a (cm²) + 5b(cm) + c.  You can't add an amount of cm² to an amount of cm to get a single quantity.  You'll find that there is never a physical reason to add an amount of cm² to an amount of cm.  It would be like trying to add 5cm + 6s.  You also can't add a unitless number to an amount of cm.  The topic exploring this idea is called dimensional analysis.

+yessopie Suppose that a and b are not dimensionless, but that a has the units of (cm^-2), b of (cm^-1), and c is dimensionless. Then, we have consistency.  Quadratic equations arise in quadratic approximations, which I believe are suitable for use in physics where the units must be consistent. Then again, in the quadratic equations that arise from the truncated taylor's series, derivatives of varying orders (and so units) are involved. Hence I suppose, as in my example in the first statement of this comment, the units may be consistent among the terms of the equation.

You're right.  I was just thinking of a, b, c as numeric constants.  A more simple example of a quadratic equation in physics is the position of a particle under constant acceleration.  Then a is the acceleration in m/s², b is the initial velocity in m/s, c is the initial position in m, and  x is in s.

@KatherineRogers Actually, if a constant k=1/1m is used, then in the final formula for V you will end up with subtracting m^1 from m^2 which is apparently not correct.

@KatherineRogers Second: If we take “a” as the height of the figure, then the equation would be V= (pi/2)h*a, (remember that height is NOT unit squared). We could also write “a” as “x”(or radius) squared, so the final equation would be V=(pi/2)h*r^2 which won’t have any problem with units. I hope I made myself clear.

@KatherineRogers First: When he says that y=x^2, he's talking about the Magnitude of x squared, not the unit squared. Here is an example: Imagine I have a sheet of paper whose width is 10 cm and its length is the width squared. The length will then be 100 cm, NOT 100 cm^2 right? This is because only the magnitude (the number itself) was squared, not the unit. The same thing happens with the problem he's solving.

Take the integral from 0meters to (a meters) if along the y axis and from 0 meters to the (square root of a meters) if along the x direction i.e. use UNITS. This helps ensure the units of the answer come out properly. Again, dont delete k in y=kx^2 because its numerically equal to one, the units are needed. k=1/(1 meter). k is exact so does not effect significant figures of your answer.

Y=x^2  NO!. Meters does not equal meters squared.  Try Y=kx^2  where k is a unit conversion factor ie 1/(1meter).In cm,  the k would be 1/(100cm)  Make SURE your equation is dimensionally correct BEFORE you work with it.  The constant k also appears in the answer making volume be in meters cubed (or cm cubed) as volume should be.  This lecture was a mess and should be redone!

that is not correct  'y = k x^2' must be used in any substitution of 'y' INCLUDING the limit calculation. 'dV = 2 pi (ax - kx^3) dx'; 'V = (2 pi ((ax^2)/2-(kx^4)/4) from 0 to sqrt(a/k)' resulting in 'V = (pi/4) (a^2)/k' (see https://www.mathcha.io/editor/7rrGpc0WSLdHDxZdJHGXxY0Gun6zLQQSq2wd3 {using 'c' instead of 'k'})
